title: Howzat? Smith's mattress investment makes a fortune
text:
Four years and 200,000 customers later, Koala is a household name which in July raised $5.3 million at a pre-money valuation of $150 million.

Even though Smith's ownership stake has diluted as Koala has gradually raised $17.5 million from external investors, the price of the latest shares issued values his parcel at $12.18 million.

Koala co-founders Mitch Taylor (left) and Dany Milham. Supplied

Smith told this newspaper in 2016 that he had a long-held interest in start-ups, and could see himself in a business career after his cricket career finished.

In 2016 he paid $100,000 for a 4 per cent stake in Snappr, an online photography platform, although its current valuation is uncertain as the business has since relocated to the US.

The Financial Review Young Rich List is set to value Smith at about $31 million when it is published in the Australian Financial Review Magazine on October 25, up from $27 million in 2018.

The sharp rise in the value of his Koala Mattress investment has helped offset reduced endorsement income following the ball-tampering scandal.

Meanwhile his income earned from cricket is back up, due to coming off suspension and being able to sign a $2 million Indian Premier league contract with the Rajasthan Royals.

Advertisement

Mr Taylor and his Koala Mattress co-founder, Dany Milham, hoped the value of Smith's Koala Mattress stake would continue to grow as they used the fresh $5.3 million to buy inventory for a planned expansion of product categories beyond mattresses and sofas.

Koala made $73 million of revenue in 2018-19, up from $44 million the year before, and although there was a loss after tax of $2.7 million, Mr Milham said the business had become profitable for the first time in the last quarter of the year.

Koala's internal creative agency recently sent comedian Sam Simmons to record a fake mattress informercial on Nine's Today Show. ninevms

"That EBIT will be invested straight into developing new proucts and Japan," he said, revealing Koala was attaining 100 per cent year-on-year growth in its only non-Australian territory.

The start-up in Japan had seen Koala "double down" on its internal creative agency, Mr Taylor said, which is known for its cheeky outdoor billboards and data-driven social media marketing strategy, which can see it test up to 25 versions of the one video to determine the best performer.

Koala now employs 80 people, including those developing Gumleaf, its customer experience platform which ensures 4-hour deliveries in metropolitan areas. Investors in its latest round include Sydney funds managers Alium and Perennial, and John Guscic, the chief executive of WebJet.
description: Australian batsman Steve Smith's investment in an online mattress designer is making him more money than playing cricket.
